history.content: Watch lecture videos from last semester before actual lecture so you can get early exposure to material! Also do lots of practice and start studying early!

children.subject:
Thanks Neil !

I watched Josh Hug's Spring 2016 lectures on YouTube and did all of the discussion worksheets. Any other advice?
Cool! Who did you take the course with? And if it was Hilfinger, did you ever go to office hours?
I had hug and occasionally went to his office hours mostly because of my schedule and I had stuff during that time. I liked it a lot!

I had this fear of going to Professor Hilfinger's office hours because I didn't want to feel stupid, but I think I'll just suck it up and go. I think I'm more concerned with what I should be taking away from this class. I got a pretty solid idea by taking the practice midterms, but I continuously struggle with code writing questions. I kinda figured out that if you're doing a problem and they give you a hint then you should probably use the hint (I know, I'm stupid).
Professor Hilfinger is super helpful, definitely go to his OH. I'm not sure where the idea of him being unapproachable came from.
Me either. He seems like a nice guy. Thank you!
I think you have done a lot so far!!! Now when you get to lecture focus on the stuff you struggled with the most and maybe find extra practice for those concepts!

Thank you! I took a total of four midterms over the summer (2 midterm 1s and 2 midterm 2s) and I made sure I understood why the answers were what they were and I pushed the material into my head, but there weren't many CS61B practice tests, only from specific years. Do you know of any websites I could visit to find the rest?
how early did you start doing practice papers? often when i start papers I feel let down because i don't do amazingly. would you have any tips on how to approach them with maximised course knowledge

Hi, OP here. I'm not exactly sure what OP means I just see other people using it and assume it's the person who originally asked the question. Could be using it wrong. Anyway, I think the most important part about taking the practice exams is studying the material before you take it and not relying on them alone to tell you what you should study. 

 I think Professor Hilfinger is very practical when he tells us that we are responsible for all the knowledge in recorded history with emphasis on this course. It's better to assume you should know everything instead of just the key points. 

Remember to tailor your studying to your own needs. Ask yourself, do I understand (insert topic here)? If there's one bit of tug in your heart that suggests "No" then spend some time doing some soul searching and figure out what it is that you don't understand. Yes, I know what a linked list is. Yes, I know you can change it using pointers. But what I didn't understand was how I could set a pointer to something and change that pointer without changing the list. Then I realized I didn't know the different between p.tail = ... and p = p.tail. Small stuff like that can have a big impact on your understanding and it's up to you to dig into yourself and find those small things to correct them. After you do it a few times you'll be able to identify what you're having trouble with in just under a minute. It all starts with a serious assessment of yourself with the proper questions. 

Finally, stopping because I feel like I'm writing too much and getting a little off topic, learn to enjoy yourself and celebrate failure. Failure two hours before an exam is stressful, but failure weeks and even days away should be exciting and you should be determined to do everything stated in the paragraph above, plus some. And if it helps, use some analogies to help your understanding. Thinking of variables as boxes is an example. It helps you remember things like how you can put a subtype in a supertype box and the otherway around with casting. 

Recap:

Study everything

Figure out what you don't know 

Ask for help, only after you know exactly what you need help with (post soul search session)

Write some code if you need to (Java interpreter, manipulate some pointers )

Watch some YouTube videos 

Make analogies

Take a practice exam

Immerse yourself in the world of Java and Data Structures!

...go to Piazza...

Hope this helped!

Practice midterms, practice midterms, practice midterms. Make sure you can not only solve the problems and get 100%, but be able to explain to your friends how to solve the problem. Same goes for the projects but to a lesser importance. And when you're confused, it's okay to communicate with other people...don't try to bash your head against the wall for hours only to find out you were missing a parentheses.

history.content:
Hi Former CS61B Students!

I'm an intended CS major and I'm taking CS61B this semester with Hilfinger. I wanted to know if you guys had any advice on how to do well in this course. I studied over the summer and really got to know Java and my Data Structures. I took practice exams and I was getting ~50% on them and I did the first two projects. Is there anything else you guys can suggest I do to get an A in this class. Any thoughts are appreciated. Thanks :)
history.subject: Calling Former CS61B Students, Advice on How to do Well
